Chapter 4.8: On The Threshold
Talk to Bróin inside the hidden cave of Drenghól
Talk to Bori outside Zarkul-sulûn during the War of Three Peaks

'One obstacle remains, my friend. We must do something about Gorgar the Ruthless, the Orc who rules Gundabad. His Orcs will defend the Mountain-home from us for as long as he lives, but if I can put an end to him they will scatter. They will learn first-hand that only a dwarf can lay claim to the title Lord of Gundabad!\n\n'Blow the signal horns to rally dwarves to my banner: outside Zarkul-sulûn, in the field of battle, and at our forward encampment nearest to the Mountain-home! I will lead my warriors up the steps on this last offensive, and on the very threshold of the fortress I will challenge Gorgar for the rule of Gundabad!'

'I am sorry, [placeholder]. We are right on the threshold of victory, but my heart is heavy.'

You ask Bróin what you can do to lighten his burden, and he frowns.

'There is nothing, my friend. These worries are my own, and...'

He trails away, engaged in some internal debate. At last he nods decisively.

'You have always stood by me and my kin, [placeholder], no matter the mistakes we have made; I will forget neither that loyalty nor those kindnesses. Neither will I keep these troubles from you, though I am shamed by them. This then is my confession, friend.

'I fear my decision to seal away the mithril axe may have cost my father his life. Would Brogur still live today if we had wielded Zigilburk in defence of the Iron Garrison? When the horde emerged from the depths of Moria, could I have repelled them if I still possessed the truest reflection of Durin's own axe in this Age of the world? I chose to seal Zigilburk away because I thought it was cursed, but can you truly say that the Iron Garrison's fate in Moria could have been worse than it was? I find that hard to believe.

'How many lives might I have saved if I kept Zigilburk, [placeholder]? How many lives in Moria, and how many lives here, on the steps of Gundabad?'

You speak what reassuring words you can, and Bróin thanks you for them, but you can tell his heart remains heavy.

'Tell my cousin Bori I am well... or well enough. He does worry.'
